prompt:
Am I in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for ending free friend rides in my car?
My friend always hops rides everywhere in my car. I fill up the tank and pick him up at his house and drop him back off safely at home. This past weekend he put 10 in gas because I forgot my purse home and yesterday he asked me back for it. He has ridden in my car hundreds of times without putting gas. Am I an asshole for saying find your way around in the future?
"""

Am I in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (I am in the wrong) and B for No (I am not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if they're an asshole for ending free rides for their friend. The friend has used their car hundreds of times without contributing to gas, but this time, after the user forgot their purse, the friend put $10 in gas when returning the purse. Then the user told the friend to find their own way around. 

First, I need to consider the context. The user has been giving their friend free rides consistently, which implies a certain understanding. The friend only contributed once when reminded (maybe indirectly through the purse situation), and the user decided to stop. 

The user's main issue is that the friend never contributed to gas before, and now they're being asked to stop. The user might feel taken advantage of, especially if they're covering all costs. The friend's one-time contribution might not be enough to justify the user's reaction. 

Is the user in the wrong? Well, if the friend was using the car without contributing, the user has the right to set boundaries. The user isn't obligated to provide rides unless there was an agreement. The friend's single act of putting gas might not be sufficient, considering the history. So, the user's decision to stop might be justified as self-respect and setting limits.

But maybe there's an unspoken agreement. If the user never explicitly said the friend had to pay, maybe the friend thought it was a free ride. But the user is now ending it, which could be seen as fair since the friend didn't contribute before. The answer would likely be B (No, not in the wrong) because the user is asserting their own needs after being taken advantage of.
